item.title: Israel launches major operation in West Bank; Palestinian officials say 9 killed
item.dc:creator: Frances Vinall
item.description: Israel’s military and internal security service said the operation was aimed at infrastructure used by militants in the cities of Jenin and Tulkarm.

item.title: A month after Venezuela’s contested election, the opposition fights on
item.dc:creator: Ishaan Tharoor
item.description: The opposition in Venezuela and its supporters have stood courageously, but risk being muffled by the Maduro regime’s suppression.

item.title: Biden approved Gaza pier despite internal pushback, watchdog finds
item.dc:creator: Dan Lamothe
item.description: The Gaza pier project faced early concerns within the U.S. government, including a warning that rough seas could pose a challenge, an inspector general found.

item.title: Hostage rescued from Gaza found alone in tunnel, Israeli military says
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Hassan, Lior Soroka, Loveday Morris
item.description: Farhan al-Qadi, 52, spent 326 days in captivity in Gaza before he was discovered by Israeli troops operating in southern Gaza.

item.title: U.S. soldier who entered North Korea will plead guilty to desertion
item.dc:creator: Victoria Bisset
item.description: Travis King, an Army private, crossed into North Korea last year and was expelled. He’ll appear at a hearing Sept. 20, his lawyer said.

item.title: In first major speech, Keir Starmer paints a gloomy picture of Britain
item.dc:creator: William Booth
item.description: The new U.K. prime minister talked about societal “rot” and financial black holes and said “things will get worse before they get better.”

item.title: Ukraine’s Zelensky says incursion into Russia part of plan to end war
item.dc:creator: Lizzie Johnson, Serhiy Morgunov
item.description: Ukraine’s top commander reported that more than a 100 settlements in Russia’s Kursk region had been taken, along with 594 prisoners of war.

item.title: U.N. says evacuation order in Gaza’s Deir al-Balah ‘upends’ aid efforts
item.dc:creator: John Hudson, Adela Suliman, Andrew Jeong, Hazem Balousha
item.description: A U.N. agency says Israel’s evacuation orders in Gaza’s Deir al-Balah area have displaced humanitarian workers and disrupted aid.

item.title: How many hostages are still in Gaza since Hamas attack on Israel? What to know.
item.dc:creator: Victoria Bisset, Sammy Westfall, Helier Cheung
item.description: Israel estimates some 117 hostages held by Hamas have been released or freed; 70 are believed still to be alive in Gaza. Here’s what we know.

item.title: Italy opens investigation into captain in deadly yacht sinking, lawyer says
item.dc:creator: Rachel Pannett, Stefano Pitrelli, Anthony Faiola
item.description: James Cutfield, a veteran sailor from New Zealand, is being investigated after the Bayesian capsized, killing seven, including tech figure Mike Lynch.

item.title: U.S. military’s Tinder ad in Middle East raises eyebrows
item.dc:creator: Ellen Nakashima, Alex Horton
item.description: An advertisement warning that U.S. fighter jets were ready to respond to provocations showed up on a dating app in Lebanon.

item.title: American dies in ice cave collapse during Iceland glacier tour
item.dc:creator: Kelsey Baker
item.description: One American died and a second was injured after an ice cave popular with tourist groups collapsed Sunday afternoon.

item.title: Arrest of Telegram’s Durov inflames debate over online crime and free speech
item.dc:creator: Pranshu Verma, Joseph Menn, Niha Masih
item.description: The arrest in France of the site’s Russia-born founder highlights ongoing disputes over social media’s responsibility for spreading child sexual abuse material and other criminal content.

item.title: Dam collapse in Sudan floods villages; local media reports dozens missing
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Hassan
item.description: At least four people died after the Arbaat dam’s collapse, according to Sudan’s Health Ministry. Local media, citing government officials, said the toll is probably higher.

item.title: Who is Pavel Durov, the Russian-born Telegram founder arrested in France?
item.dc:creator: Niha Masih
item.description: Durov, who founded Telegram with his brother, has an estimated net worth of $15 billion. He was born in the Soviet Union and now lives in Dubai.

item.title: Russia strikes energy infrastructure across Ukraine, forcing power outages
item.dc:creator: David Stern, Serhiy Morgunov
item.description: The attack focused on the power sector comes just days after Ukraine celebrated its independence from the Soviet Union.

item.title: How Israel and Hezbollah stepped back from the brink of all-out war
item.dc:creator: Steve Hendrix, John Hudson, Susannah George, Suzan Haidamous, Mohamad El Chamaa
item.description: Analysts and officials said the potentially disastrous exchange of fire along the Israel-Lebanon border Sunday had become a face-saving moment for both sides.

item.title: She was beaten and bullied for being trans. This pageant gave her pride.
item.dc:creator: Michael E. Miller, Matthew Abbott
item.description: In the Pacific nation of Tonga, the growth of Christian evangelical churches is hardening attitudes toward leitis: people born as men who live “like a lady.”

item.title: Scores of detainees in Maduro’s post-election roundup are children
item.dc:creator: María Luisa Paúl
item.description: Maduro’s forces have arrested children as young as 13, rights advocates say. More than 100 remain in custody weeks after Venezuelans began protesting his suspect victory claim.
